member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the BlockCacheSettings class.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheSettings.BlockSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the size (in bytes) of each cached block.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheSettings.ReadCacheSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the size (in bytes) of the read cache.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheSettings.LargeReadSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum read size that will be cached.
member.remarks: Large reads are not cached, on the assumption they will not be repeated. This setting controls what is considered 'large'. Any read that is more than this many bytes will not be cached.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheSettings.OptimumReadSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the optimum size of a read to the wrapped stream.
member.remarks: This value must be a multiple of BlockSize

member.name: T:DiscUtils.BlockCacheStatistics
member.summary: Statistical information about the effectiveness of a BlockCache instance.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheStatistics.LargeReadsIn
member.summary: Gets the number of requested 'large' reads, as defined by the LargeReadSize setting.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheStatistics.UnalignedReadsIn
member.summary: Gets the number of requested unaligned reads.
member.remarks: Unaligned reads are reads where the read doesn't start on a multiple of the block size.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheStatistics.TotalReadsIn
member.summary: Gets the total number of requested reads.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheStatistics.TotalReadsOut
member.summary: Gets the total number of reads passed on by the cache.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheStatistics.ReadCacheHits
member.summary: Gets the number of times a read request was serviced (in part or whole) from the cache.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheStatistics.ReadCacheMisses
member.summary: Gets the number of time a read request was serviced (in part or whole) from the wrapped stream.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheStatistics.UnalignedWritesIn
member.summary: Gets the number of requested unaligned writes.
member.remarks: Unaligned writes are writes where the write doesn't start on a multiple of the block size.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheStatistics.TotalWritesIn
member.summary: Gets the total number of requested writes.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheStatistics.FreeReadBlocks
member.summary: Gets the number of free blocks in the read cache.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.Buffer.Clear(System.Int64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Clears bytes from the buffer.
member.param: The start offset within the buffer.
The number of bytes to ckear

remarks.para: Logically equivalent to writing count null/zero bytes to the buffer, some implementations determine that some (or all) of the range indicated is not actually stored. There is no direct, automatic, correspondance to clearing bytes and them not being represented as an 'extent' - for example, the implementation of the underlying stream may not permit fine-grained extent storage.
It is always safe to call this method to 'zero-out' a section of a buffer, regardless of the underlying buffer implementation.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.Buffer.Flush
member.summary: Flushes all data to the underlying storage.
member.remarks: The default behaviour, implemented by this class, is to take no action.

member.returns: An enumeration of stream extents, indicating stored bytes

member.name: T:DiscUtils.IBuffer
member.summary: Interface shared by all buffers.
member.remarks: Buffers are very similar to streams, except the buffer has no notion of 'current position'. All I/O operations instead specify the position, as needed. Buffers also support sparse behaviour.

member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this buffer can be modified.

member.summary: Gets the current capacity of the buffer, in bytes.

member.summary: Gets the parts of the buffer that are stored.
member.remarks: This may be an empty enumeration if all bytes are zero.

member.summary: Reads from the buffer into a byte array.
member.param: The offset within the buffer to start reading.
The destination byte array.
The start offset within the destination buffer.
The number of bytes to read.
member.returns: The actual number of bytes read

member.name: M:DiscUtils.IBuffer.Write(System.Int64,System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Writes a byte array into the buffer.
member.param: The start offset within the buffer.
The source byte array.
The start offset within the source byte array.
The number of bytes to write.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.IBuffer.Clear(System.Int64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Clears bytes from the buffer.
member.param: The start offset within the buffer.
The number of bytes to clear

remarks.para: Logically equivalent to writing count null/zero bytes to the buffer, some implementations determine that some (or all) of the range indicated is not actually stored. There is no direct, automatic, correspondance to clearing bytes and them not being represented as an 'extent' - for example, the implementation of the underlying stream may not permit fine-grained extent storage.
It is always safe to call this method to 'zero-out' a section of a buffer, regardless of the underlying buffer implementation.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.IBuffer.Flush
member.summary: Flushes all data to the underlying storage.

member.summary: Sets the capacity of the buffer, truncating if appropriate.
member.param: The desired capacity of the buffer.

member.summary: Gets the parts of a buffer that are stored, within a specified range.
member.param: The offset of the first byte of interest
The number of bytes of interest
member.returns: An enumeration of stream extents, indicating stored bytes

member.name: M:DiscUtils.SparseStream.Clear(System.Int32)
member.summary: Clears bytes from the stream.
member.param: The number of bytes (from the current position) to clear

remarks.para: Logically equivalent to writing count null/zero bytes to the stream, some implementations determine that some (or all) of the range indicated is not actually stored. There is no direct, automatic, correspondance to clearing bytes and them not being represented as an 'extent' - for example, the implementation of the underlying stream may not permit fine-grained extent storage.
It is always safe to call this method to 'zero-out' a section of a stream, regardless of the underlying stream implementation.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.VirtualDisk.IsPartitioned
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the disk appears to have a valid partition table.
member.remarks: There is no reliable way to determine whether a disk has a valid partition table. The 'guess' consists of checking for basic indicators and looking for obviously invalid data, such as overlapping partitions.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.VirtualDisk.Partitions
member.summary: Gets the object that interprets the partition structure.
member.remarks: It is theoretically possible for a disk to contain two independant partition structures - a BIOS/GPT one and an Apple one, for example. This method will return in order of preference, a GUID partition table, a BIOS partition table, then in undefined preference one of any other partition tables found. See PartitionTable.GetPartitionTables to gain access to all the discovered partition tables on a disk.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.VirtualDiskLayer
member.summary: Represents the base layer, or a differencing layer of a VirtualDisk.

remarks.para: VirtualDisks are composed of one or more layers - a base layer which represents the entire disk (even if not all bytes are actually stored), and a number of differencing layers that store the disk sectors that are logically different to the base layer.
Disk Layers may not store all sectors. Any sectors that are not stored are logically zero's (for base layers), or holes through to the layer underneath (all other layers).

member.name: T:DiscUtils.MappedStream
member.summary: Base class for streams that are essentially a mapping onto a parent stream.
member.remarks: This class provides access to the mapping underlying the stream, enabling callers to convert a byte range in this stream into one or more ranges in the parent stream.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.MappedStream.FromStream(System.IO.Stream,DiscUtils.Ownership)
member.summary: Converts any stream into a non-linear stream.
member.param: The stream to convert.
true to have the new stream dispose the wrapped stream when it is disposed.
member.remarks: The wrapped stream is assumed to be a linear stream (such that any byte range maps directly onto the parent stream)

member.name: M:DiscUtils.MappedStream.FromStream(System.IO.Stream,DiscUtils.Ownership,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{DiscUtils.StreamExtent})
member.summary: Converts any stream into a non-linear stream.
member.param: The stream to convert.
true to have the new stream dispose the wrapped stream when it is disposed.
The set of extents actually stored in stream
member.remarks: The wrapped stream is assumed to be a linear stream (such that any byte range maps directly onto the parent stream)

member.name: M:DiscUtils.MappedStream.MapContent(System.Int64,System.Int64)
member.summary: Maps a logical range down to storage locations.
member.param: The first logical range to map
The length of the range to map
member.returns: One or more stream extents specifying the storage locations that correspond to the identified logical extent range.

remarks.para: As far as possible, the stream extents are returned in logical disk order - however, due to the nature of non-linear streams, not all of the range may actually be stored, or some or all of the range may be compressed - thus reading the returned stream extents is not equivalent to reading the logical disk range.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.VolumeInfo
member.summary: Base class that holds information about a disk volume.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.VolumeInfo.BiosType
member.summary: Gets the one-byte BIOS type for this volume, which indicates the content.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.VolumeInfo.Length
member.summary: Gets the size of the volume, in bytes.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.VolumeInfo.Identity
member.summary: Gets the stable volume identity.
member.remarks: The stability of the identity depends the disk structure. In some cases the identity may include a simple index, when no other information is available. Best practice is to add disks to the Volume Manager in a stable order, if the stability of this identity is paramount.

member.summary: Gets the disk geometry of the underlying storage medium (as used in BIOS calls), may be null.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.VolumeInfo.PhysicalStartSector
member.summary: Gets the offset of this volume in the underlying storage medium, if any (may be Zero).

member.name: M:DiscUtils.VolumeInfo.Open
member.summary: Opens the volume, providing access to it's contents.
member.returns: Stream that can access the volume's contents.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.VolumeManager
member.summary: VolumeManager interprets partitions and other on-disk structures (possibly combining multiple disks).

remarks.para: Although file systems commonly are placed directly within partitions on a disk, in some cases a logical volume manager / logical disk manager may be used, to combine disk regions in multiple ways for data redundancy or other purposes.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.VolumeManager.GetPhysicalVolumes(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Gets the physical volumes held on a disk.
member.param: The contents of the disk to inspect

remarks.para: By preference, use the form of this method that takes a disk parameter.
